questions.text: Name the structure marked below that runs from the junction of the falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli to the confluence of sinus ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sinus that begins at the junction of the falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli and drains into the confluence of sinuses is the straight sinus.

  • The straight sinusis one of the main dural venous sinuses and is found at the junction between the falx cerebri and the tentorium cerebelli and is triangular in cross-section.
  • Receives blood from the inferior sagittal sinus and the great cerebral vein (of Galen)
  • Drains posteriorly into the confluence of sinuses, located at the internal occipital protuberance
  • It is part of the system that ultimately drains blood from the deep and medial aspects of the brain.
  • Although the exact drainage is variable:
    • Confluence of sinuses (56%)
    • Left transverse sinus (21%)
    • Right transverse sinus (13%)
  • It is occasionally duplicated or hypoplastic.
  • When absent a persistent falcine sinus is usually identified, draining directly into the superior sagittal sinus.

Explanation of other options:

Superior sagittal sinus (Option A) : Lies along the attached superior margin of the falx cerebri; does not lie at the tentorial junction.

Inferior sagittal sinus (Option B) : Lies within the free inferior edge of the falx cerebri and drains into the straight sinus, not the confluence directly.

Cavernous sinus (Option D) : Located on either side of the sella turcica, it drains facial and cerebral veins but has no anatomical relation to the falx cerebri or tentorium cerebelli.

questions.text: A patient presents with periorbital edema, eyelid erythema, chemosis, ptosis and high-grade fever with spikes. The patient has a history of tonsillitis and otitis media. Examination shows paralysis of extra ocular muscles, loss of pupillary reflex and loss of corneal reflex. Visual acuity is preserved. What is most likely involved with this disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked arrow in the CT scan shows cavernous sinus.

  • The given scenario explains paralysis of extra ocular muscles, loss of pupillary reflex and loss of corneal reflex.
  • It means there is paralysis of the oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve, abducens nerve and ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve, though the optic nerve is spared.
  • This suggests infection of cavernous sinus which is marked above.
  • High fever with spikes explains Picket fence fever.
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST) is a rare, life-threatening disorder that can complicate facial infection, sinusitis, orbital cellulitis, pharyngitis, or otitis or following traumatic injury or surgery, especially in the setting of a thrombophilic disorder.
  • Early recognition of cavernous sinus thrombosis which, often presents with fever, headache, eye findings such as periorbital swelling, and ophthalmoplegia, is critical for a good outcome.
  • Despite modern treatment with antibiotics and anticoagulation, the risk of long-term sequelae, such as decreased vision, diplopia, and stroke, remains significant.

questions.text: A patient presents with blurred vision, confusion, memory loss, numbness in the left side of the body, problems with thinking, reasoning, memory and speech. Further examination reveals carotid artery stenosis. Which of the following branches of the internal carotid artery will not be involved in this case ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The caroticotympanic branch arises within the petrous part of the internal carotid artery, before it reaches the brain, and hence would not be involved in cerebral ischemia due to carotid stenosis affecting intracranial circulation.

There are seven segments of internal carotid artery in the Bouthillier classification:

  • C1: cervical segment - No branches
  • C2: petrous (horizontal) segment - Gives off caroticotympanic and artery of the pterygoid canal
  • C3: lacerum segment
  • C4: cavernous segment - Gives off small branches to the trigeminal ganglion, meninges, and cavernous sinus
  • C5: clinoid segment
  • C6: ophthalmic (supraclinoid) segment
  • C7: communicating (terminal segment)

In carotid artery stenosis, especially intracranial or supraclinoid, the affected branches are those beyond the cavernous segment which are responsible for cerebral perfusion and explaining symptoms like memory loss, confusion, numbness, and speech impairment.

  • The cavernous segment has -
    • Branch to trigeminal ganglion
    • Meningeal branch
    • Branch to cavernous sinus
    • Hypophyseal branch

The caroticotympanic artery, being in the petrous (bony) part, supplies the middle ear cavity and is not related to cerebral blood flow, so it is not involved in ischemic neurological deficits.

questions.text: Which of the following veins is formed by union of the two internal cerebral veins, basal vein of rosenthal and supplies straight sinus as its tributary ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The great cerebral vein of Galen is formed by the union of the two internal cerebral veins and basal veins (of Rosenthal) and drains into the straight sinus

  • The great cerebral vein (vein of Galen) is a short but large unpaired midline vein located beneath the splenium of the corpus callosum.
  • It plays a key role in the deep venous drainage of the brain.
    • Formation:
      • Two internal cerebral veins (each drains thalamus, caudate nucleus, and adjacent structures)
      • Two basal veins of Rosenthal (drain medial temporal lobe, midbrain, and basal ganglia)
    • Drainage:
      • The great cerebral vein drains directly into the straight sinus, which then drains into the confluence of sinuses, contributing to cerebral venous return.
  • Clinically, obstruction of this vein or straight sinus can lead to venous infarction, hydrocephalus, or deep cerebral hemorrhage.

Explanation of other options:

Middle cerebral vein (Option A) : Drains superficial lateral surfaces of the cerebral hemisphere into the cavernous sinus; not involved in deep cerebral drainage.

Anterior cerebral vein (Option C) : Drains the medial surface of the cerebral hemisphere, but does not unite with basal veins or drain into the straight sinus.

Posterior communicating artery (Option D) : This is an artery, not a vein; it connects the internal carotid and posterior cerebral artery in the circle of Willis.

questions.text: Which of the following sinuses do not drain into A?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked part is the confluence of veins that receives drainage from the straight, superior sagittal, and occipital sinuses, but not from the cavernous sinus, which drains elsewhere.

  • The confluence of sinuses (also called the torcular Herophili) is a dilated venous space located at the internal occipital protuberance, where several dural venous sinuses converge.
  • Sinuses that drain into the confluence:
    • Superior sagittal sinus (usually on the right)
    • Straight sinus (formed by inferior sagittal sinus and vein of Galen; usually drains to left transverse sinus)
    • Occipital sinus
  • Sometimes the posterior end of the falcine sinus (in neonates).
  • Cavernous sinus drainage:
    • Drains via the superior and inferior petrosal sinuses
    • These ultimately drain into the sigmoid sinus or internal jugular vein
    • Cavernous sinus does not connect directly to the confluence
